CatDescriptText: Joseph McBurney, stockbroker, Crafton Heights and Catherine Thomaszewski, beautician, Coraopolis, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, April 22, 1961, pg. A1 with question: "Do you think that Negroes, when unable to obtain a 'square deal,' in politics, should register a 'protest' vote by voting for Negro candidates on a ticket, or should they utilize other tactics to protest and continue to vote for all candidates who are qualified and will serve their interests best?" Joseph McBurney's answer reads: "I think they should vote Republican and that would solve the problems."  Catherine Thomaszewski's answer reads: "They should take other action if the candidate or candidates they nominate and elect won't help them."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Joseph McBurney wearing eyeglasses, dark patterned necktie, light colored sweater, and dark coat, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Catherine Thomaszewski wearing earrings, coat with large collar, and light colored gloves, holding handbag over right arm, standing in front of Bud Saunders Flowers in Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
